generalitesTitle: OVERVIEW OF THE CAMEROONIAN HIGHER EDUCATION SYSTEM
quote:
Education is not a name of any degree or certificate that can be shown to others as a proof.
Education is the name of our attitude, actions, language and behavior with others in real life.
paragraph1: Last level of the formal education system, higher education is under the supervision of the Ministry of Higher Education. However, there are a number of higher education institutions with special status, each of which comes under the joint authority of the Ministry of Higher Education and the ministry responsible for the sector (see Higher Education Institutions).
paragraph2: In addition, there is a vocational training pathway leading to vocational diplomas (Senior Technicians) and certificates offered by vocational training centers and some PHEI under the supervision of the Ministry of Employment and Vocational Training and the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development.
paragraph3: This section aims basically to give high school students and fresh GCE AL Holders or International students the key information on the Cameroonian Higher Education System.
accessIntro: Cameroon is home of two educational subsystems: An English-speaking subsystem in force in the North-West and South-West regions and a French-speaking subsystem in the eight other regions. As a result, access to higher education is open to students holding one of the following two diplomas rewarding the end of the secondary level:
diplomasIntro: The General Certificate of Education Advanced Level (GCE A-Level), general or technical, for the English-speaking subsystem; and
diploma1: Le General Certificate of Education Advanced Level – GCE A/L – (général ou technique) pour le sous-système anglophone ;
diploma2: The Baccalauréat de l’Enseignement Secondaire (general or technical) for the French-speaking subsystem
tableHeader2: Admission to Postgraduate degrees (Master, MBA, PhD…)
tableRow1Col1: On pre-registration and application followed or not by file study for holders of a GCE A/L or Baccalauréat; or,
tableRow1Col2: Selective in both public and private institutions (excellent academic records required);
tableRow2Col1: On nationwide entrance examination for technological or vocational programs (STEMM-Courses in public, private or transnational Institutions).
tableRow2Col2: By competitive entrance examination or file study followed by an interview for Bachelor’s or Master’s degree holders.
noteText: Foreign diplomas recognised equivalent to Baccalauréat / A-Level and Certifying Professional Experience in some specific cases, may also grant an access to higher education.

content2.title: Cameroonian higher education architecture
content2.paragraph2: Since the 2007/08 academic year, Cameroon has moved to the BMD System (Bachelor, Master, Doctorate/PhD), organised in three training cycles:

cycle.title: A first cycle
cycle.text: leading to a Bachelor’s degree (6 semesters);

cycle.title: A second cycle
cycle.text: leading to a Master’s degree (4 semesters);

content2.paragraph3: Besides these three cycles, there are also short vocational cycles leading to the High National Diploma (HND) and the High Professional Diploma (HPD). State universities generally offer full undergraduate and postgraduate programs, while most of the Private Institutions only offers undergraduate programs.
content2.paragraph4: Within the BMD system, the courses are measured in credits; these can be transferred and capitalised from one course to another. The course period covers a semester equivalent to 30 credits.
content2.credit2: Master = 120 credits after the Bachelor degree
content2.credit3: PhD = 180 credits after the Master degree
content2.paragraph7: The degrees can take different forms: general (academic or research) and vocational programs, the number and duration of which vary according to the institution and the field of study. Academic programs are not commonly linked with any specific type of work, while vocational programs are directly linked to particular jobs.
content2.paragraph9: The teaching programs are diversified but do not cover many advanced technological and scientific fields, such as nanotechnology, robotics, aerospace, etc.

content3.title: School fees & costs
content3.intro: Decree No 93/033 of 19 January 1993 sets the rates of payment of university fees in public institutions as follows:
content3.paragraph2: Cameroonians: Fifty thousand CFA francs (around 90 USD) per academic year, to be paid in one or two instalments.
content3.paragraph3: N.B.: This amount applies largely to generalist courses; the cost of vocational programs is generally higher.
content3.paragraphe_foreign_student: Foreign students: Subject to reciprocity and the conventions in force, foreign students pay following fees:
content3.para: 300,000 CFA francs (around 550 USD) in the Faculties of Arts, Humanities, Law, Politics, Economics and Management.
content3.paragraph4: Foreign students: Subject to reciprocity and the conventions in force, foreign students pay following fees:
content3.paragraph5: 600,000 CFA francs (around 1,100 USD) in the Faculties of Science and University Institutes of Technology.
content3.paragraph6: 1,000,000 CFA francs (around 1,700 USD) in the Faculties of Medicine and Pharmacy, in Schools and Professional Training Establishments. (Art. 3).
content3.paragraph9: School fees at private and transnational institutions are far higher than at public institutions, they vary from institution to institution and start at around 200,000 CFA francs (around 350 USD) per year for low-ranking institutions and go up to several million CFA francs (more than 1,500 USD) for prestigious institutions.

logement.title: Student population & Accommodation
logement.paragraph1: The student population has been steadily increasing over the years. At the start of the 2022/23 academic year, 413,888 students were enrolled in Cameroonian universities, including 294,189 in public institutions and 119,699 in Private. Foreign student represented 10% of the total number.
logement.paragraph2: Cameroonian students have three options for accommodation:
logement.paragraph4: (Monthly rents are generally agreed with the university and vary between 15,000 and 35,000 CFA francs depending on the city and the building’s standard).
logement.paragraph7: 3. With relatives or the family house.
logement.paragraph8: Most of the students live in private-owned residencies and in family houses. The Host Family option is less common in Cameroon.
logement.paragraph9: Rooms of public residencies on-campus are normally granted in priority to students with disabilities or from disadvantaged social backgrounds and foreigners.

content4.title: Recognition of Cameroonian degrees abroad
content4.paragraph1: As a general rule, Cameroonian diplomas are not automatically recognised abroad. Consequently, the latter must be recognized by the competent authority in the host country or by the university the student applies for. The recognition procedure is expensive and relatively long, between 4 to 6 months depending on the country. For more specific advice, contact the British Council’s Cameroon Office for studies in the UK or Campus France Cameroun for studies in France. Also see our section Studying abroad for more information to this topic.
